{{Infobox musical artist | name = Gabriel Brown | image =Gabriel Brown b1910.jpg | caption =Gabriel Brown, photographed by [[Carl Van Vechten]] in 1935 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1910
[[Florida]], [[United States]] | death_date = 1972
Florida, United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Piedmont blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1935–1952 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Gabriel Brown''' (1910–1972) was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[guitarist]]. ==Biography== Brown was born in [[Florida]], and graduated from the Florida Agricultural and Mechanical College. In 1934, Brown performed at the first [[National Folk Festival (USA)|National Folk Festival]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]]. He was musically discovered by [[Folkloristics|folklorist]] [[Zora Neale Hurston]]. She enlisted [[Alan Lomax]] who, in June 1935, recorded Brown for the [[Library of Congress]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p184669/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Gabriel Brown |author=Chadbourne, Eugene |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 4, 2010}}{{cite book | first= Bruce | last= Bastin | year= 1995 | title= Red River Blues | edition= | publisher= University of Illinois Press | location= Illinois | isbn= 0-252-01213-5 | page= 58}} Similar to [[Ralph Willis (blues musician)|Ralph Willis]], [[Alec Seward]] and [[Brownie McGhee]], Brown then relocated from the [[Southern United States]] to [[New York City]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | page= 190}} Hurston gave Brown a part in her [[light opera]], ''Polk County''. In 1935 Brown started a four-year tenure with the Federal Arts Theatre, initially under [[Orson Welles]]' direction. By the late 1930s, Brown appeared as a singer on [[Cincinnati]] radio, and took part in the show ''St. Louis Woman''. He found employment with the [[civil service]], working for the [[Signal Corps (United States Army)|Army Signal Corps]] in [[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]], [[New Jersey]]. Brown had Joe Davis as his [[record producer]] on his first full recording session in 1943, and the twosome worked together until Brown's final sessions in 1952. In 1945 Brown sang, "I can't have no luck at all, the jinx is on me."{{cite web |url= http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art61162.asp |title=Folklore and Mythology Site |author=Phyllis Doyle Burns |date= |work= |publisher=Bellaonline.com |accessdate=May 25, 2011}} Several of Brown's recordings were not released during his lifetime, and some of those that were issued were not always promoted tastefully or accurately. In the late 1940s, various tracks were licensed to [[Coral Records]]. Eventually Davis worked in [[Artists and repertoire|A&R]] for [[MGM Records]], and Brown followed him to that label, where he was promoted as a [[popular music|pop]] singer. Later [[compilation album]]s were released on [[record label]]s such as [[Flyright Records|Flyright]]. Gabriel Brown died by [[drowning]] in Florida in 1972, following a boating accident. ==Selected discography== *''Gabriel Brown'' (2001) – [[Catfish Records]]{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r542310|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Gabriel Brown > Overview )))}} ==See also== *[[List of Piedmont blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.wirz.de/music/browngab.htm Illustrated Gabriel Brown discography] {{Persondata | NAME = Brown, Gabriel | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] singer and guitarist | DATE OF BIRTH = 1910 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Florida]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = 1972 | PLACE OF DEATH = Florida, United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brown, Gabriel}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:People from Florida]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Florida]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Piedmont blues musicians]] [[Category:Blues musicians from Florida]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Florida]]
